title: What to Wear on a Ghost Tour
content:
The fastest way to ruin a ghost tour isn't fear—it's discomfort. I've watched people drop out halfway through tours because of bad shoes, thin jackets, or clothes chosen for style instead of walking. What you wear matters more on ghost tours than most travelers expect.

What are the universal clothing rules?

Comfort comes first. Ghost tours involve standing, slow walking, and long periods outdoors. Wear broken-in walking shoes, breathable layers, and clothes you can move in easily. Dark clothing isn't required, but reflective accessories or loud colors can feel out of place on night tours. Pockets help more than backpacks.

Clothing by tour format

Different tour formats have different clothing needs:
  • Walking tours – Comfortable shoes are critical; you'll cover 1-2 miles
  • Bus/trolley tours – Less walking, but dress for getting on/off in weather
  • Cemetery tours – Sturdy shoes for uneven ground; layers for exposed settings
  • Investigation tours – Often in unheated buildings; dress warmer than expected
  • Pub crawls – Balance indoor warmth with outdoor walking

What should you wear in summer?

In hot climates, lightweight fabrics and moisture-wicking tops make a difference. Even night tours can stay warm in cities like New Orleans or Savannah. Closed-toe shoes are still important. Sandals may feel cooler, but uneven streets and long standing periods make them impractical.

What should you wear in fall?

Fall is ideal ghost tour weather, but temperatures can drop quickly after sunset. Layering is key. A light jacket, long sleeves, and comfortable walking shoes handle most conditions. Scarves and hats help on windier nights without adding bulk.

What should you wear in winter?

Winter ghost tours require insulation. Thermal layers, gloves, and weather-resistant outerwear matter more than appearance. Cities like Edinburgh and Boston can feel significantly colder at night due to wind and damp air. Warm footwear with good traction is essential.

What should you never wear?

Avoid new shoes, high heels, or anything that restricts movement. Costumes are usually discouraged unless the tour explicitly allows them. Open-toed shoes, heavy bags, and clothing that requires constant adjustment will distract you from the experience.

Special considerations

  • Kids on ghost tours – Dress them in layers they can manage themselves
  • Solo travelers – Keep valuables secure in zippered pockets
  • Couples – Coordinate comfort levels for shared enjoyment

What to bring

Beyond clothing, a few items enhance the experience:
  • Small flashlight for uneven terrain
  • Phone for photos (see our ghost photography tips)
  • Water bottle for longer tours
  • Cash for tipping guides
Leave large bags at your hotel—they slow you down and bump into other participants.

Does the city climate matter?

Absolutely. Coastal cities tend to be humid and windy, while older stone cities retain cold. Always check evening weather forecasts, not daytime highs. When in doubt, dress slightly warmer than you think you'll need. Standing still feels colder than walking.

Practical Takeaway

Dressing correctly for a ghost tour means staying present instead of preoccupied. Comfortable shoes, smart layers, and climate awareness will improve the experience more than any accessory. For tour format context, start with the complete ghost tour guide.
